#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Prune a Gardenia Bush
#Text=Gardenia bushes are a lovely addition to any garden , but if left alone they can get a little scraggly .
#Text=Make sure you prune after your gardenias are finished blooming , and that you use sharp pruning shears .
#Text=You should first remove any dead blooms , and then trim back shoots that alter the natural shape of the gardenia bush .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Removing Dead Stems
#Text=Pinch off dead stems with your fingers .
#Text=Throughout its flowering season , regularly look over the plant for dead blooms – they ’ll be brown or black and look generally unhealthy .
#Text=With your thumb and index finger , pinch behind the swollen seed base that ’s behind the base of the bloom .
#Text=Pull the dead stem off the branch .
#Text=This practice is known as “ deadheading . ”
#Text=You may need to use hand pruners for thicker stems .
#Text=" Deadhead " your gardenia bush once a week during blooming season .
#Text=Look for and pinch off dead or fading flowers once a week .
#Text=Removing them regularly can encourage the growth of longer-lasting flowers , and can also increase the number of flowers that will bloom later .
#Text=Time your pruning right .
#Text=If you prune your gardenia bush with shears before it ’s finished blooming , you could cause damage to the growing blooms .
#Text=Instead , plan on pruning your gardenia bush after the blooming season is over , but before the daytime temperature falls below .
#Text=You 'll know it 's time to prune the bush once see the flowers begin to fade .
#Text=Prune the bush 1 or 2 weeks after the flowers fade .
#Text=Pruning for Shape , Size , and Growth
#Text=Use standard pruning shears when trimming gardenias .
#Text=For branches that are up to thick , use common hand-held pruning shears .
#Text=In the unlikely event that you have branches larger than that , use a narrow-bladed saw .
#Text=Disinfect your shears ( and saw , if needed ) before using them .
#Text=Mix a solution of 1 part rubbing alcohol to 1 part water .
#Text=Dip the blades into the solution , or apply it to a clean rag and wipe down the blades .
#Text=However , if it 's been awhile since you 've used your shears , let the blades soak in the solution for 10 minutes or so .
#Text=Then let your shears air dry .
#Text=You can also use a solution of 1 part bleach to 9 parts water .
#Text=Wipe down the blades after cutting any diseased or infected branches , and when moving from one plant to another .
#Text=If you do n't disinfect your shears , you could accidentally transfer any insects or disease from one branch ( or plant ) to another .
#Text=Step back to determine the size and shape of your gardenia bush .
#Text=Stand far enough away from your gardenia bush that you can see the whole thing in comparison to the area around it .
#Text=Then decide what size and shape you 'd like the bush to be .
#Text=Once you begin pruning , step back frequently to check to make sure you 're maintaining the size and shape you want .
#Text=Hold the pruning shears at a 45-degree angle to the branch .
#Text=This angle will help you cut through the branches easily .
#Text=It also prevents you from damaging the main branches of the bush if you get too close .
#Text=Cut away half of the oldest branches at the trunk .
#Text=Cutting the oldest , thickest branches will allow space for new growth .
#Text=Depending on how overgrown your gardenia bush is , you might want to trim out more than half of the oldest branches .
#Text=The oldest branches tend to be the darkest shade of brown and the thickest .
#Text=Trim the remaining branches down to your desired height and shape .
#Text=After you 've thinned out the oldest branches , trim the remaining branches .
#Text=As you 're trimming the branches , make sure you make cuts above a stem branch or leaf node to encourage new growth there .
#Text=The stem branch is where thinner stems branch off of thicker limbs .
#Text=The leaf node is the bulge at the end of the leaf stem at the branch .
#Text=Prune most where you want to encourage growth .
#Text=In addition to pruning your gardenia bush to maintain its shape and size , you can prune to encourage growth in certain areas .
#Text=If you prune back the bottom of the gardenia bush beyond the excess growth – up to a few inches – that area will tend to grow back fuller .
#Text=Maintaining Your Gardenia Bush
#Text=Water your gardenias regularly .
#Text=Regular watering will promote thick foliage and bloom growth .
#Text=The soil around your gardenia bush should almost always be moist .
#Text=How often you 'll need to water your gardenia bush will depend on how dry the weather is .
#Text=Fertilize your gardenia bush 2 to 3 times per year .
#Text=One of the best times to fertilize your gardenia bush is after you prune it .
#Text=Use a fertilizer with a a 3-1-2 or 3-1-3 ratio of nitrogen , phosphorus , and potassium .
#Text=Follow the instructions on the fertilizer packaging for the amount you should use , and mix it into the soil around your gardenia bush .
#Text=Check for bugs on your gardenias .
#Text=You should look for mealybugs , caterpillars , aphids , whiteflies , thrips , and spider mites .
#Text=If you see any of these insects on your gardenia bush , try a natural remedy to remove them .
#Text=If the infestation is bad , you may need to use an insecticide .
#Text=To get rid of aphids , spray them with water every 2-3 days until they disappear .
#Text=For whiteflies and spider mites , try applying neem oil or insecticidal soap to your gardenia bush .
#Text=Use your hands to pick caterpillars off your gardenia bush
#Text=Quick Summary
